aws::graph::propositions: # Amazon System Interruption and Redundancy Risks
Amazon experiences occasional system interruptions and delays.
System interruptions make Amazon websites unavailable.
System interruptions make Amazon services unavailable.
System interruptions prevent Amazon from efficiently accepting orders.
System interruptions prevent Amazon from efficiently fulfilling orders.
System interruptions prevent Amazon from efficiently providing services to customers.
System interruptions prevent Amazon from efficiently providing services to third parties.
System delays make Amazon websites slow to respond.
System delays make Amazon services slow to respond.
System interruptions may reduce Amazon's net sales.
System interruptions may reduce the attractiveness of Amazon's products.
System interruptions may reduce the attractiveness of Amazon's services.
Amazon takes steps to add software to improve systems.
Amazon takes steps to add hardware to improve systems.
Amazon upgrades its systems and network infrastructure.
Amazon works to improve the stability of its systems.
Amazon works to improve the efficiency of its systems.
Steps taken by Amazon may not be sufficient to avoid system interruptions.
Steps taken by Amazon may not be sufficient to avoid system delays.
System interruptions could adversely affect Amazon's operating results.
System delays could adversely affect Amazon's operating results.
Amazon faces risks related to system interruption.
Amazon faces risks related to lack of redundancy.

statements.value: Amazon faces risks related to system interruption.
Amazon faces risks related to lack of redundancy.

text:
##### We Face Risks Related to System Interruption and Lack of Redundancy

We experience occasional system interruptions and delays that make our websites and services unavailable or slow to respond and prevent us from efficiently accepting or fulfilling orders or providing services to customers and third parties, which may reduce our net sales and the attractiveness of our products and services. Steps we take to add software and hardware, upgrade our systems and network infrastructure, and improve the stability and efficiency of our systems may not be sufficient to avoid system interruptions or delays that could adversely affect our operating results.
